Starting Attributes: STR <var 20 E802 /var>/DEX <var 20 E804 /var>/VIT <var 20 E803 /var>/INT <var 20 E805 /var>/MND <var 20 E806 /var><tab><tab>

Hyur<var 09 E802 (( ©)) (( ®)) (()) /var><tab><tab>The Hyur are said to have first traveled to Eorzea from her surrounding<nl>continents and islands. Three great migratory waves later, they are now<nl>the most populous of all the civilized races. They exhibit a relatively<nl>modest physique, both in height and build, and are known for their<nl>peculiarly short, rounded ears. Hyurs are well suited for traveling long<nl>distances by foot, a trait thought to account for their swift proliferation.<nl><nl>Their espousal of an eclectic variety of languages and traditions is<nl>a legacy of their diverse heritage－as is their resulting lack of a<nl>unified cultural identity.

Elezen<var 09 E802 (( ©)) (( ®)) (()) /var><tab><tab>In former times, the Elezen were the sole inhabitants of Eorzea,<nl>claiming dominion over her. Traditionally a nomadic people, the tall,<nl>slender Elezen believed the realm to be theirs by divine right.<nl>Unfortunately, this belief made the eventual appearance of the<nl>Hyur in their multitudes akin to an invasion, and a long history of<nl>conflict ensued.<nl><nl>Ultimately, the Elezen diverged into the two clans that exist today.<nl>The Wildwood Elezen took to the forests to protect their homeland,<nl>while the Duskwight Elezen withdrew to caves and subterrane, opting<nl>instead to avoid all contact with any but their own.

Lalafell<var 09 E802 (( ©)) (( ®)) (()) /var><tab><tab>A wee people sporting short, rotund bodies, the Lalafell appear as<nl>no more than children to the eyes of most. Many of these nimble<nl>little folk hail from the islands of the south seas, where they practice<nl>a simple agricultural lifestyle. It was not until the opening of maritime<nl>trade routes that the gradual migration of Lalafells to Eorzea began.<nl><nl>Now one of the most well-established races in the realm, Lalafells<nl>can be found in great numbers in nearly every city. Though Lalafellin<nl>culture places great emphasis on blood relations, individuals are known<nl>for getting along amicably with members of all races.

Miqo'te<var 09 E802 (( ©)) (( ®)) (()) /var><tab><tab>The ancestors of the Miqo'te made their way to Eorzea during the<nl>Age of Endless Frost, traversing the frozen seas in pursuit of the<nl>wildlife upon which they subsisted. Adaptation to a hunting lifestyle<nl>has fashioned them with a keen sense of smell, powerful legs, and<nl>a tail which provides them with exceptional balance.<nl><nl>Miqo'te are known to be very territorial, and many individuals tend<nl>to lead solitary lifestyles, particularly males.

Roegadyn<var 09 E802 (( ©)) (( ®)) (()) /var><tab><tab>Known for their brawny builds and piercing eyes, the Roegadyn<nl>are the largest and most rugged of Eorzea's races. The majority<nl>of the realm's Roegadyn belong to the Sea Wolf clan, a maritime<nl>people who earn their keep on or by the sea, be it as sailors,<nl>fishermen, or pirates. Comparatively fewer in number are the<nl>Hellsguard, who are known for their more earnest demeanors<nl>and can often be found working as bodyguards and smithies.

Midlander<tab><tab>The Midlander clan comprises over half of the total population of<nl>Eorzea's Hyurs. They have established themselves throughout<nl>every city in the realm and lead lives as diverse as their heritage.<nl><nl>Trained in letters from infancy, the Midlanders are generally more<nl>educated than many of the other races and clans. Despite the fact<nl>that males tend to be slightly taller than females, there are no<nl>significant differences between the genders.

Highlander<tab><tab>The Highlanders were the first of the Hyur to reach Eorzea.<nl>Their name derives from their long tradition of building strongholds<nl>in the mountains. Compared to their Midland brethren, the<nl>Highlanders are noticeably larger in build.<nl><nl>Of late, Highlanders have become an increasingly rare sight<nl>in Eorzea, their number represented almost exclusively by those<nl>who fled Ala Mhigo after its fall and now work in the desert<nl>city-state of Ul'dah as mercenaries and sellswords.

Wildwood<tab><tab>For hundreds of years, the Wildwood Elezen have lived in the<nl>relative safety of Eorzea's lush forests. With the formation of<nl>Eorzea's governments, however, many Wildwood ventured forth<nl>from the forests, drawn to the exhilarating cosmopolitanism of<nl>nearby Gridania. There is minimal dimorphism between the two<nl>genders, though males are generally considered to be milder and<nl>more chivalrous in demeanor. Among their Duskwight brethren,<nl>Wildwood Elezen are referred to as Greens, for their love of the forest.

Duskwight<tab><tab>Centuries ago, a number of Elezen sought out a life of peace and<nl>seclusion in the depths of Eorzea's caves and caverns. Today,<nl>they are called the Duskwight, though to their Wildwood cousins<nl>they are known simply as the Greys, after their preference for<nl>darkness and stone.<nl><nl>The cave-dwelling ways of the Duskwight persist, with some<nl>among them turning to robbery and pillaging to survive, earning<nl>them the scorn of their woodland relatives. There are few<nl>differences between the genders, but Duskwight females are<nl>often regarded as being the more passionate and unyielding of<nl>the two.

Plainsfolk<tab><tab>From the flat landscapes of the Plainsfolk's home islands are where<nl>this Lalafellin clan takes its name. Their distinct hair coloration－<nl>a myriad of earthy and grassy tones－helps them to blend in well<nl>with their environment, acting as an effective camouflage against<nl>would-be attackers. It was the similarity of La Noscea's grassy<nl>fields to those in their homeland which drew the first settlers to<nl>the island of Vylbrand and what is now Limsa Lominsa.<nl><nl>They are a clever and opportunistic people, and crafty with<nl>their words. The generally accepted view of Plainsfolk is that<nl>they are a vibrant lot, with a penchant for excessive conversation.

Dunesfolk<tab><tab>Perhaps the most unique characteristic of the Dunesfolk is their<nl>luminous eyes─a result of a glossy, protective layer which covers<nl>the pupil, an evolutionary response to their homeland's glaring sunlight.<nl>Many individuals wear a small, traditional gemstone on their forehead,<nl>a symbol of their zodiacal sign. They are adamant about scholasticism,<nl>placing the advancement of knowledge before all else. Other races<nl>tend to perceive male Dunesfolk as introverts who care more for<nl>books, business, and the prosperity of Ul'dah─a city-state built upon<nl>Dunesfolk ingenuity─than the goings-on of the rest of the realm.

Seekers of the Sun<tab><tab>The self-proclaimed Seekers of the Sun are the diurnal clan of<nl>the Miqo'te race. Their preference for the warm light of day<nl>pervades all aspects of their culture, as is apparent in their<nl>devout reverence for Azeyma, the Warden, keeper of the sun<nl>and goddess of inquiry.<nl><nl>They are perhaps known best for their striking eyes－the result<nl>of their vertically aligned pupils and faintly colored irises. It is also<nl>not uncommon for their eyes to be disparately colored from birth,<nl>a trait considered auspicious amongst their kind.<nl><nl>Seeker tribes can be found throughout Eorzea, with large<nl>concentrations appearing near Limsa Lominsa and the Sagolii Desert.

Keepers of the Moon<tab><tab>The nocturnal among the Miqo'te have dubbed themselves the<nl>Keepers of the Moon. Shying from the garish light of day, they<nl>revel in the shroud of night, with most offering their piety to<nl>Menphina, the Lover, goddess of the moon.<nl><nl>They are distinguishable from their diurnal cousins by their<nl>darker fur, larger ears, rounder eyes, more pronounced canines,<nl>and longer, skinnier tails. The ritual application of war paint to<nl>the face is still regularly practiced, as it is believed the vivid<nl>colors grant lunar powers.<nl><nl>After a great many summers of conflict with the people of<nl>Gridania, the Keepers have finally made amends with the<nl>people of the sylvan city-state, with some even choosing<nl>to make their homes there.

Sea Wolves<tab><tab>Long ago, no vessel or coastal village was safe from<nl>the fury of the Sea Wolves and their maritime brand<nl>of brutality. The mere mention of the clan was enough<nl>to strike fear into the hearts of any who drew their<nl>livelihood from the sea. The Sea Wolves originally hail<nl>from the islands of the far north seas, where they still<nl>subsist as fishermen and women.<nl><nl>It was not until the large-scale deployment of Limsa<nl>Lominsa's armada that the Sea Wolves' appetite for<nl>piracy diminished. Now, it is not uncommon to see them<nl>employed as sailors or naval mercenaries on all manner<nl>of vessels. However, they have never forgotten the<nl>ways of their homeland, and still use the ancient<nl>Roegadyn language in their names.

Hellsguard<tab><tab>The Hellsguard are a Roegadyn clan with body and mind<nl>tempered by the unforgiving heat of the volcanic regions<nl>they inhabit. Believing these mountains of flame to be<nl>gates to the underworld, their line has for centuries<nl>stood vigil to prevent the passage of souls back to the<nl>realm of the living.<nl><nl>As the harsh environs of their homelands produce<nl>little sustenance, the second- and third-born are often<nl>sent forth from their mountain villages, with many and<nl>more making their way to the great cities. It is there that<nl>their sheer girth and steely demeanors place them in<nl>high demand as soldiers and sellswords, allowing the<nl>young of even the largest families to surpass their<nl>elder siblings in prosperity.

Au Ra<var 09 E802 (( ©)) (( ®)) (()) /var><tab><tab>The curved horns and beautifully patterned scales that characterize<nl>the Au Ra oft give rise to speculation that members of this Hyur-like<nl>race native to the Far Eastern continent of Othard are, in fact, the<nl>progeny of dragons. This, however, has long been disputed, with<nl>scholars citing several distinct differences in the two races as<nl>evidence of decidedly dissimilar roots─the first and foremost being<nl>the enhanced hearing and spatial recognition granted by an Au Ra's<nl>cranial projections (traits not attributed to draconian horns), and the<nl>second being the gross disproportion in body mass between Auri<nl>males and females (again, a trait widely unseen in dragons).

Raen<tab><tab>Auri creation myth tells of a Dawn Father and a<nl>Dusk Mother from whom all Au Ra are descended.<nl>The Raen believe their veins to run thick with the<nl>blood of the former─their brilliant white scales and<nl>iron wills serving as proof of this divine lineage.<nl><nl>Unlike their sister clan, the Xaela, who bloody the<nl>land with endless tribal conflict, the Raen have<nl>embraced a life of tranquility and solitude, long<nl>abandoning the nomadic lifestyle of their ancestors<nl>to settle the deep valleys of Othard's mountainous<nl>eastern reaches. Only on rare occasions will one<nl>emerge from the valley mists to seek adventure<nl>in realms afar.

Xaela<tab><tab>Auri creation myth tells of a Dawn Father and a<nl>Dusk Mother from whom all Au Ra are descended.<nl>The Xaela believe their veins to run thick with the<nl>blood of the latter─their lustrous black scales and<nl>fiery wills serving as proof of this divine lineage.<nl><nl>Unlike their sister clan, the Raen, who lead solitary<nl>lives hidden behind the savage peaks of Othard's<nl>eastern reaches, the Xaela are free spirits who<nl>roam the vast western steppe in close-knit tribes<nl>hunting, gathering, and warring as their ancestors<nl>have for countless generations.

Gladiator<tab> <tab>Gladiators specialize in the handling of all manner of one-handed<nl>blades, from daggers to longswords, be they single- or double-edged,<nl>straight or curved. A defining characteristic of the art is its emphasis<nl>on diverse combat tactics, training its members to bring their martial<nl>skills to bear in any situation. As such, there are practitioners who<nl>marry sword with shield, seeking to defend their fellow companions.<nl>Others opt for an empty off hand, choosing instead to focus entirely<nl>on their sword arm. In all instances, the ages-old art of the sword<nl>makes the gladiator a formidable adversary in any encounter.<nl><nl>Corresponding Job: Paladin

Pugilist<tab> <tab>The path of the pugilist is one of incessant training aimed at mastering<nl>the traditional techniques of hand-to-hand combat. Though they<nl>command formidable power when unarmed, they are wont to use metal,<nl>leather, and bone weaponry to maximize their destructive potential.<nl><nl>Their preference for fighting at close quarters makes negotiating<nl>distances an absolute necessity. This is why many pugilists are quick<nl>to learn that lightweight gear allowing for maximum agility ensures them<nl>better success in battle than does cumbersome plate or chain.<nl><nl>Corresponding Job: Monk

Marauder<tab> <tab>The marauder is a combat specialist whose weapon of choice is<nl>the greataxe－a fearsome arm emblematic of Eorzea's pirates.<nl>Their approach to battle is one of brute force, relying on strength<nl>and steel to crush enemies and sunder weapons. They are highly<nl>sought after for their ferocity and intimidating presence, and are<nl>often employed to hunt down monsters plaguing the land, or to turn<nl>the tide of battle between warring nations.<nl><nl>Corresponding Job: Warrior

Lancer<tab> <tab>The strategy of the lancers is to outrange and fluster opponents<nl>with their long, two-handed polearms, peppering them with a barrage<nl>of thrusting attacks. They are trained with a number of weapons,<nl>giving a diversity to their attacks that makes them extremely<nl>versatile combatants.<nl><nl>In former times, the longspear saw the most widespread use,<nl>due in great part to the influence of the proud lancer legions of<nl>Ala Mhigo. Since then, the guild has greatly expanded its armories<nl>to include a variety of weaponry, such as the halberd and the trident.<nl><nl>Corresponding Job: Dragoon

Archer<tab> <tab>The enduring popularity of the bow is a testament to its elegant<nl>design, but this simple weapon would be of little worth without the<nl>surpassing skill of those who master it－the archers. Projectile<nl>techniques such as high-angle fire enable archers to assail their<nl>foes with deadly precision even at great distances.<nl><nl>Constant assessment of the battlefield enables them to carefully<nl>determine the most advantageous ground from which to loose,<nl>as well as the nature of the arrows best suited to their enemy.<nl>Together with the longbow sentries of the Elezen military, the<nl>shortbow hunters among the Miqo'te are widely regarded as<nl>most skilled with the bow.<nl><nl>Corresponding Job: Bard

Conjurer<tab> <tab>Conjury calls upon elemental forces present in nature and concentrates<nl>them to a potency at which spells can be woven. Through practiced<nl>meditation on the essences of creation, conjurers draw forth and<nl>absorb aether from their immediate surroundings. A wand or cane<nl>made from unworked wood is then utilized to focus the aether until it<nl>manifests as the desired spell. The seat of the Conjurers' Guild lies at<nl>Stillglade Fane in Gridania, where the voices of Eorzea's elementals are<nl>said to be most powerful.<nl><nl>Corresponding Job: White Mage

Thaumaturge<tab> <tab>In the hands of a skilled practitioner, thaumaturgy can be a force of<nl>terrifying destruction. At the heart of this school of magic lies the<nl>ability to call forth and command the latent aether within oneself<nl>through deep introspection. To then mold that aether into sorcery,<nl>the thaumaturge makes use of a scepter or staff, within which is<nl>housed a medium－a natural stone imbued with magical properties.<nl><nl>Corresponding Job: Black Mage

Arcanist<tab> <tab>Adepts of the art of arcanum derive their might from symbols of power<nl>born of geometric techniques hailing from across the southern seas.<nl>Held within occult grimoires, these symbols lend shape to the arcanist's<nl>aether, thereby allowing him to produce myriad powerful spells. Using<nl>the selfsame symbols to unlock the latent power contained within<nl>gemstones, arcanists are also able to summon forth the familiar known<nl>as Carbuncle to carry out their bidding.<nl><nl>Corresponding Jobs: Summoner, Scholar
Blacksmith<tab><tab>不要：新生ではキャラメイクで選択できるのは戦闘職のみ。
Miner<tab><tab>不要：新生ではキャラメイクで選択できるのは戦闘職のみ。

Hrothgar<var 09 E802 (( ©)) (( ®)) (()) /var><tab><tab>Hailing from the distant shores of Ilsabard, the Hrothgar are a burly<nl>people of lionlike appearance—or the males are, at least. Females<nl>number staggeringly few among their population, and thus are<nl>rarely so much as glimpsed by the other races.<nl><nl>The Hrothgar's imposing countenance─mitigated not at all by their<nl>sharp claws and still sharper fangs—incited panic amongst<nl>Eorzeans upon their arrival. As they were also unable to<nl>communicate, initial interactions with the commonfolk often<nl>escalated into conflict. It was not until the Hrothgar gained mastery<nl>of the common tongue that fears were allayed, and in time they<nl>would be as neighbors, welcome in all corners of the realm.

Viera<var 09 E802 (( ©)) (( ®)) (()) /var><tab><tab>Of tall stature and slender frame, the Viera's physical appearance is<nl>strikingly similar to that of the Hyur and Elezen, save for their<nl>distinctive long ears. Adhering to a strict code known as the Green<nl>Word, they are prohibited from contact with the outside world under<nl>threat of exile. Their society is purely matriarchal, and males of age<nl>are seldom, if ever, found within the bounds of any village. They<nl>instead serve as protectors of the wood from the shadows, that no<nl>evil may ever encroach on their sacred lands.

Helions<tab><tab>Helions have traditionally been content to reside in southern Ilsabard<nl>with their respective tribes, devout servants to their queens,<nl>one and all—and thus have they only but recently begun to make<nl>their presence felt throughout the remainder of the three continents.<nl>Though these Hrothgar initially had no word to describe themselves,<nl>scholars came to call them "Helions" after observing how their lives<nl>all but revolved about their queen's needs, as planets circle the sun.

The Lost<tab><tab>Unlike their Helion brethren, the Lost are unbound by the whims of any<nl>reigning monarch, having long since found themselves bereft of the<nl>warm radiance of their queen. Most find that a nomadic lifestyle<nl>best suits their situation, and are known to ply a variety of trades<nl>that align with their propensity to travel—seasonal laborer,<nl>mercenary, and peddler among them.

Rava<tab><tab>Viera of the Rava clan live primarily in the Golmore Jungle, their<nl>umber skin allowing them to readily blend in with their surroundings.<nl>Though the males stand as wards of the forest, the females are<nl>adept hunters and protectors in their own right, fiercely guarding their homes and<nl>their young. Despite attempts by the Dalmascans to subjugate<nl>them, they have ever maintained a self-governing dominion. Though<nl>most would adhere to the traditions of the wood, some few have<nl>chosen to venture out into the world.

Veena<tab><tab>With skin as fair as the snowcapped mountains towering above, the<nl>Veena clan make their homes in the forests lining the southwestern<nl>foothills of the Skatay Range. Like the members of their sister clan,<nl>the Veena live as hunters and gatherers, laboring not only to protect<nl>the woods, but to nurture them. As the winds of war swept up a<nl>number of those who left their mountain homes, many such<nl>hardened hunters chose to set out for the distant shores of Eorzea.

Halone, mover of glaciers and goddess of war, is the guardian deity of Ishgard. She commands the element of ice and is associated with the first moon of the Eorzean calendar. Halone is the daughter of Rhalgr, and a bitter rival of Nophica. She is most often depicted as a relentless warrioress armed with a bronze greatshield. Her symbol is the three spears.<tab><tab>

Menphina is keeper of the moon and the goddess of love. She commands the element of ice and is associated with the second moon of the Eorzean calendar. Menphina is the sister of Azeyma, and the divine lover of Oschon. She is most often depicted as a maid carrying a round skillet. Her symbol is the full moon.<tab><tab>

Thaliak, ruler of rivers and wisdom, and god of knowledge, is the guardian deity of Sharlayan. He commands the element of water and is associated with the third moon of the Eorzean calendar. Thaliak is the father of Llymlaen, and the teacher of Byregot. He is most often depicted as a reserved scholar holding an ashen staff. His symbol is the scroll.<tab><tab>

Nymeia is the watcher of celestial bodies and goddess of fate. She commands the element of water and is associated with the fourth moon of the Eorzean calendar. Nymeia is the younger sister of Althyk, and master of Rhalgr. She is most often depicted as a weaver donning a white silken veil. Her symbol is the spinning wheel.<tab><tab>

Llymlaen, watcher of the seas and goddess of navigation, is the guardian deity of Limsa Lominsa. She commands the element of wind and is associated with the fifth moon of the Eorzean calendar. Llymlaen is the daughter of Thaliak, and the elder sister of Nophica. She is most often depicted as a strong fisherwoman wielding a long-bladed harpoon. Her symbol is the wave.<tab><tab>

Oschon is ruler of the mountains and god of travelers and vagrants. He commands the element of wind and is associated with the sixth moon of the Eorzean calendar. Oschon is the brother of Nald'thal, and the close companion of Halone. He is most often depicted as a carefree ranger wielding a bow of yew. His symbol is the walking stick.<tab><tab>

Byregot is the purveyor of architecture and industry, and god of the arts. He commands the element of lightning and is associated with the seventh moon of the Eorzean calendar. Byregot is the elder brother of Halone, and pupil of Thaliak. He is most often depicted as an ardent smith with a two-headed hammer. His symbol is the hand.<tab><tab>

Rhalgr, breaker of worlds, is the god of destruction and guardian deity of the now-fallen nation of Ala Mhigo. He commands the element of lightning and is associated with the eighth moon of the Eorzean calendar. Rhalgr is the father of both Byregot and Halone, and serves as attendant to Nymeia. He is most often depicted as a magus carrying a staff of bronze. His symbol is the streaking meteor.<tab><tab>

Azeyma is keeper of the sun and goddess of inquiry. She commands the element of fire and is associated with the ninth moon of the Eorzean calendar. Azeyma is the daughter of Althyk, and the elder sister of Menphina. She is most often depicted as a noble lady holding a golden fan. Her symbol is the radiant sun.<tab><tab>

Nald'thal, overseer of the underworld and god of commerce, is the guardian deity of Ul'dah. He commands the element of fire and is associated with the tenth moon of the Eorzean calendar. Nald'thal is the single manifestation of the deific twins Nald and Thal. He is most often depicted as a discerning merchant holding a balance. His symbol is the cowry, an ancient shell currency.<tab><tab>

Nophica, tender of soils and harvests, and goddess of abundance, is the guardian deity of Gridania. She commands the element of earth and is associated with the eleventh moon of the Eorzean calendar. Nophica is the daughter of Azeyma, and the younger sister of Llymlaen. She is most often depicted as a jubilant farmer holding a scythe of steel. Her symbol is the spring leaf.<tab><tab>

Althyk is the surveyor of change and space, and god of time. He commands the element of earth and is associated with the twelfth moon of the Eorzean calendar. Althyk is the father of Azeyma and Menphina, and elder brother to Nymeia. He is most often depicted as an austere emperor wielding a mythril greataxe. His symbol is the hourglass.<tab><tab>

All data centers within the same region offer the same quality of gameplay.)) /var><tab><tab>

“World” is another name for the server on which your character will reside. Once you have chosen a Home World, chances to move to another will be limited, so if you have made plans to play FINAL FANTASY XIV with friends, make certain that you all select the same one.
Worlds are divided between nine different data centers based on the location of their servers. To ensure you encounter the fewest number of latency issues, it is recommended, but not required, that you select a data center that is closer to where you will be playing. Legacy Worlds (servers existing since the original launch) are indicated in parentheses.

Tank<tab> <tab>Stand as a bulwark in the face of danger.<nl>With superior defensive abilities, tanks protect their comrades<nl>by diverting enemy focus and bearing the brunt of battle.<nl><nl>Begin your journey as a gladiator or marauder, and later master<nl>the jobs of paladin, warrior, dark knight, and gunbreaker.

Healer<tab> <tab>Provide succor to all in need.<nl>Though limited in their offensive abilities, healers replenish<nl>health and protect their comrades with myriad rejuvenating skills.<nl><nl>Begin your journey as a conjurer, and later master the jobs of<nl>white mage, scholar, astrologian, and sage.<nl>※Please note that the job of scholar is unlocked via the <nl>DPS class of arcanist.

DPS<tab> <tab>Decimate your foes.<nl>Possessing great talent for the offensive, DPS is a role whose sole<nl>focus is to rout the enemy with a diverse array of punishing attacks.<nl><nl>Begin your journey as a pugilist, lancer, archer, thaumaturge, or<nl>arcanist. From there, master the jobs of monk, dragoon, ninja, samurai,<nl>reaper, viper, bard, machinist, dancer, black mage, summoner, red mage,<nl>pictomancer, and blue mage.<nl><nl>Note that the DPS role is divided into three categories.<nl>Melee DPS specializes in close combat; physical ranged DPS wields arms<nl>such as guns and bows; and magical ranged DPS uses arcane powers to<nl>assert dominance upon the battlefield.

Eorzean Calendar<tab><tab>The Eorzean year consists of the moon, Menphina, revolving<nl>around Hydaelyn's two astral and umbral poles while fluctuating<nl>between each of the six elements. In this, the year can be said<nl>to be the length of twelve moons.
Adjust lighting and time of day.<tab><tab>

Limsa Lominsa<tab><tab>On the southern coast of the island of Vylbrand, under the shadow of<nl>ancient cliffs worn by the relentless onslaught of the Rhotano Sea,<nl>lies the thalassocracy of Limsa Lominsa. Its economy is driven<nl>primarily by shipping, but boasts lucrative shipbuilding, fishing, and<nl>smithing industries as well. To maintain the safety of its maritime<nl>routes, the city employs a formidable navy known as the Knights<nl>of the Barracuda. Even so, pirate bands run rampant in nearby waters,<nl>reaving and pillaging.

Gridania<tab><tab>In the eastern reaches of the Aldenard landmass, home to vast, dense<nl>woodlands and coursing rivers, lies the forest nation of Gridania. The<nl>cityscape is a mosaic of labyrinthine waterways and great wooden<nl>structures, so gracefully constructed they seem a part of the<nl>surrounding environment. The favored goddess of the citizenry is<nl>Nophica, the Matron, but great faith is also placed in the wisdom of<nl>the Seedseers－young oracles who guide the nation based on the<nl>will of the forest's elementals.

Ul'dah<tab><tab>The bustling commercial hub of Ul'dah sits amid the desolate desert<nl>landscape of southern Aldenard. Ul'dahn culture is known for its<nl>affluence, and the wealth of the nation comes in large part from its<nl>abundant mineral resources and clothcrafting industry. Though it is<nl>the sultana who claims sovereignty, true power is wielded by the<nl>Syndicate, a council sat by six of Ul'dah's most elite and influential.<nl>Nald'thal is the nation's patron deity, and two great halls devoted to<nl>His two aspects lie in the east and west of the city.
